intro: Laphamia aglossa, commonly known as the narrow-leaf larkspur, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Ranunculaceae family, characterized by its showy, blue to purple flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils in open habitats such as meadows and slopes. It has slender, branched stems with narrow, lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. Laphamia aglossa is known for its toxic properties, containing alkaloids that can be harmful to livestock and humans.
